text.author: Wiktionary
text.title: school
text.summary1: (human1) This dictionary entry for the word 'school' gives its pronunciation /skuːl/, etymologies for its senses a group/to form a group of fish (from Middle English scole, Proto-Germanic *skulō 'crowd') and elementary school/to educate (from Proto-Germanic *skōla, from Late Latin schola, Ancient Greek σχολεῖον), along with cognates and usage examples as both noun and verb.
text.summary2: (claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) This dictionary entry for 'school' outlines its dual etymology from Middle English, first meaning "group/multitude" and second meaning "place of education," provides pronunciation (/skuːl/), and details various definitions including groups of fish, educational institutions, art movements, and schools of thought, along with related verb forms.
text.summary3: (gpt4o) This dictionary entry for the word 'school' presents its pronunciation /skuːl/, etymology tracing back to Proto-Indo-European *(s)kʷel- meaning "crowd" and Ancient Greek σχολή meaning "leisure", its definitions as a noun referring to both an educational institution and a group of fish, alternative forms like 'schole', and verb usage meaning to educate or train.
text.summary4: (Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct; postedited) The term "school" has multiple meanings, referring to a group of fish, an educational institution, a place of learning, or a method of teaching, with various etymologies and cognates across Germanic languages.
text.summary5: (Qwen2.5-3B-Instruct) This dictionary entry for the word 'school' provides its etymology surpassed in Middle English, cognates, pronunciations, definitions as a noun and verb, synonyms, and usage examples across various contexts including education, marine life, and art movements.
